summary.seg: This is a composite manuscript containing mainly Patristic homilies, whose parts were probably copied mostly in the 14th century. The authors who feature most prominently are John Chrysostom and Gregory of Nazianzus, but there are also individual texts by Anastasios of Sinai, Ephraem Syrus, Epiphanios of Constantia, Sophronios of Jerusalem and Gregory of Antioch. Some losses have been substituted by the insertion of replacement leaves.

Besides the main patristic body of the manuscript, a shorter portion has been added to the beginning of the manuscript containing a table giving the date of Easter for the years 1404/5-1491/2. This may have been produced for addition to this manuscript or reused from elsewhere. There are also a few folios reused as endleaves and drawn from liturgical manuscripts, bearing fragments of prayers and hymns.

In the 16th or 17th century the manuscript was owned by the sakelliou of the Metropolitan of Rhodes, a priest or deacon responsible for the supervision of parish clergy. It was later owned by one Ioannes Borelius, perhaps the 17th-century Neapolitan scientist and mathematician Giovanni Alfonso Borelli, before being acquired later that century by the collector Thomas Gale.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [a-d] + i-ix, [x] + 1-88, 90-236, 240-355 + [xi-xiii] + [e-g] in Arabic and Roman numerals, in pencil, recto, upper right. There is no lacuna in the text between ff. 88 and 90, so the number 89 appears to have been omitted erroneously.

ff. 1-355 bear an earlier foliation in Greek numerals with the numbers αʹ-οβʹ, οδʹ-οθʹ, παʹ-πηʹ, πʹ, πθʹ-ριγʹ, ριγʹ-ριηʹ, ρκʹ-ρπγʹ, ρϙγʹ-ρϙδʹ, ρπδʹ-ρϙβʹ, ρϙεʹ-σζʹ, σηʹ/σθʹ, σιʹ-σιγʹ, σκβʹ-σκθʹ, σιδʹ-σκαʹ, σλʹ-σλζʹ, σμʹ-σμηʹ, σνϛʹ-σξγʹ, σμθʹ-σνεʹ, σξδʹ-τνεʹ (1-72, 74-79, 81-88, 80, 89-113, 113-118, 120-183, 193-194, 184-192, 195-207, 208/209, 210-213, 222-229, 214-221, 230-237, 240-248, 256-263, 249-255, 264-355), in black ink, recto, upper right. The order of this foliation reflects the correct order of the folios, now greatly disordered, but contains occasional errors.
supportDesc.condition: Much of ff. i-ii and [xi-xiii] has been lost, there is slight pest damage to ff 351-355, and there have been smaller losses to the edges of some other folios. Much of this damage has been repaired with Japanese paper. There is extensive water staining, which has caused softening of the paper in many places, and fading of the ink, which has been extensively overwritten by a later hand (e.g. ff. 87v-97r). There are areas of dirt.

physDesc.additions: A contents list to ff. 142r-355v in Latin and Greek has been added on f. [d] recto by a 17th or 18-century hand. A 19th-century hand has added a contents list to ff. ii recto-194r in Latin and Greek on f. [c] verso.

binding.p: 18th-century binding with grey paper covering over couched-laminate boards, with a white parchment spine and plain pastedowns. The classmark appears on the spine on patches.

physDesc.accMat: At each end of the manuscript are three paper endleaves belonging to the current binding. Besides the early endleaves described in full, there is one paper left endleaf (f. [d]) older than the current binding, but more recent than the remainder of the manuscript.

history.provenance: Owned in the 16th or early 17th century by the sakelliou of Rhodes, as indicated by the note on f. [x] verso.
Owned by one Ioannes Borelius, perhaps the scientist and mathematician Giovanni Alfonso Borelli (1608-1679)Borelli, Giovanni Alfonso, 1608-1679, as indicated by the note on f. 28r.

Owned by the antiquary Thomas Gale (c. 1635-1702)Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702, Fellow of Trinity and Dean of York. It appears in the 1697 catalogue of Gale's collection contained in Trinity College MS O.5.38 (p. 172).
history.acquisition: Donated by Thomas's son, the antiquary Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, in 1738.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: Catalogus codicum hagiographicorum graecorum Germaniae, Belgii, Angliae
Codices Chrysostomici Graeci I Codices Britanniae et Hiberniae
Repertorium Nazianzenum. Orationes, textus Graecus. 2, Codices Americae, Angliae, Austriae

series.title: Studien zur Geschichte und Kultur des Altertums. Reihe 2, Forschungen zu Gregor von Nazianz

monogr.title: Codices Chrysostomici Graeci VIII: I: Codices Ancyrae et Constantinopolis II: Addenda et Corrigenda ad volumina I-IV

msItem.title: Calendrical notes
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end
msItem.incipit: f. i verso [...]ιγʹ κ[...]η ηλιου
msItem.explicit: f. i verso [...]χης ναπ
msItem.note: f. i recto is blank apart from later notes and pen-trials

msItem.title: Easter table for 6913-7000 AM (1404/5-1491/2 CE)
msItem.incipit: f. ii recto Ἔτους ͵ϛϠιγʹ κύκλου ἡλίου κεʹ σελήνης κύκλου ιϛʹ
msItem.explicit: f. ix recto ἡ νηστεία τῶν ἁγίων ἀποστόλων ἡμέρας ιαʹ
msItem.note: f. ix verso is blank apart from a later note

collation.p: This part consists of a single quire, a quinion

list.item: Quire 110-1 ff. i-ix The first folio has been lost or cancelled.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. i verso A single column of at least 16 lines. 120 110
ff. ii recto-ix recto A single column of 18-19 lines. 113 95

handNote.p: f. i verso were copied by Hand C in rough mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with moderate variation in letter size. Diacritics appear only occasionally, and there is no visible punctuation.
ff. ii recto-ix recto were copied by Hand D in mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in brown ink.
Breathings are round.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: Items begin with simple minor initials in brown ink.

physDesc.additions: There are brief Greek notes and pen-trials by various hands in the margins and on the otherwise blank ff. i recto and ix verso.

history.origin: This quire was probably copied in 1404, as the Easter table appearing here begins with 6913 AM (1404/5 CE). This would be consistent with the style of script and the use of eastern paper.

msItem.title: Word-list
msItem.note: A fragment of a text written on a reused portion of what was originally a larger sheet of paper
msItem.incipit: f. [x] recto η προ τινι / να πιασι
msItem.explicit: f. [x] recto αλαδιδια
msItem.note: f. [x] verso is blank apart from later notes

collation.p: This part consists of part of a single folio inserted between the two adjoining, previously existing parts.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. f. [x] recto A single surviving column of at least 20 lines. 115 75

handNote.p: f. [x] recto was copied by Hand E in a rough mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in brown ink, with little variation in letter size. Diacritics and punctuation are not present.

physDesc.additions: On f. [x] verso are various Greek notes and pen-trials by different hands, including a note of ownership by the sakelliou of the metropolitan see of Rhodes, dating to the 16th or early 17th century: Τὸ παρὸν βιβλίον ὑπάρχει τοῦ ἐντιμοτάτου σακελλίου, τῆς ἁγιωτάτης μητροπόλεως Ῥόδου, κὺρ. This person's name was evidently intended to follow, but was never written.

history.origin: The script of the original text on this reused fragment is difficult to date, but was copied probably in the 16th or 17th century. It was inserted at some point after the preceding quire had been combined with the part that follows, as red ink from the initial letter on the following f. 1r had been transferred to the preceding. f. ix verso.

msItem.author: Anastasios of Sinai (c. 640-c. 700)
msItem.title: Homilia in sextum psalmum
msItem.rubric: f. 1r Τοῦ ὁσίου πατρὸς ἡμῶν, Ἀναστασίου τοῦ Σινᾶ ὅρους, λόγος περὶ νηστείας, εἰς τὸν ἔκτον ψαλμὸν, εὐλόγησον Πατέρ
msItem.incipit: f. 1r Πρέπουσαν τῆς τω νηστειῶν ἀρχῆς εἰλικρινοῦς μετανοίας ὑπόθεσιν
msItem.explicit: f. 26r προσκύνοισης καὶ μεγαλοπρέπεια νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ, καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: De patientia et de consummatione huius saeculi
msItem.rubric: f. 28r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· Λόγος περὶ ὑπομονῆς καὶ περὶ συντελίας τοῦ αἰῶνος τοῦτου καὶ δευτἔρας τοῦ Κυρίου παρουσίας· ἀδιαδοχου τὲ τῆς δικαίων βασιλείας καὶ ἀτελευτήτου τῶν ἁμαρτωλῶν κολἄσεως· καὶ πρὸ τῆς τῶν θείων γραφῶν μελέτην προτροπή· τίνες τὲ αἱ μεθοδίαι τοῦ ἐχροῦ καὶ τὸ τῆς ἡσυχίας ὀφέλιμον:- Δέσποτα εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 28r Λαμπρὸς ὁ βίος τῶν ἁγίων· πῶς δὲ λαμπρύνεται
msItem.explicit: f. 49r ὧ πρέπει δόξα σὺν τῶ παντοκράτορι Πατρὶ καὶ τῶ Ἁγίω Πνεύματι· νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: De patientia sermo 1
msItem.rubric: f. 49r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου, λόγος εἰς τοὺς κοιμηθέντας, Κύριε εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 49r Φέρε σήμερον μάλιστα τῶν προτέρων ἡμερῶν σπουδεώτερον
msItem.explicit: f. 69v εἴη τὸ ὄνομα Κυρίου εὐλογημένον ἀπὸ τοῦ νῦν καὶ ἕως τοῦ αἰῶνος, ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: In Iohannem homiliae 1-88
msItem.rubric: f. 69v Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου, λόγος περὶ ἐλεημοσύνης· καὶ ὅτι κρεῖττον μὴ ηλέειν, ἥπερ ἐξ ἀδικίας καὶ πλεονεξίας· καὶ ὅτι δεῖ ἐκκλίνειν ἀπὸ κακοῦ, καὶ οὕτως ποιεῖν τὸ ἀγαθόν· καὶ ὅτι· ἀδιάφορον ἀνίπτοις χερσὶν, κοινωνεῖν, Κύριε εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 69v Ἀγαπητοὶ γλυκὺς παρὼν βίος· καὶ πολλῆς γέμων ἡδονῆς
msItem.explicit: f. 74v μεθ'οὗ τῶ Πατρὶ δόξα, ἅμα τῶ Ἁγίω Πνεύματι, εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας, ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: In Iohannem homiliae 1-88
msItem.rubric: f. 74v Τοῦ αὐτοῦ περὶ φιλοχρηματίας λόγος καὶ περὶ πλουσίων καὶ φιλαργύρων, καὶ διὰ τί εἴρηται εἰδωλολατρεία, ἡ φιλαργυρία· καὶ περὶ ἐλεημοσύνης καὶ μετανοίας, Κύριε εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 74v Ἀγαπητοὶ· ἀκολουθήσωμεν ἀγαθῶ δεσπότη θέλοντι τὴν σωτηρίαν ἡμῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 90r μεθ'οὗ τῶ Πατρὶ δόξα, ἅμα τῶ Ἁγίω Πνεύματι· εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: In Iohannem homiliae 1-88
msItem.rubric: f. 90r Τοῦ αὐτοῦ Ἰωάννου τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου καὶ οἰκουμενικοῦ διδασκάλου, λόγος περὶ ἁμαρτίας καὶ τῆς μελλούσης καὶ τελευτήτου κολάσεως· καὶ περὶ πορνείας· καὶ μοιχείας· καὶ ὅτι μοιχεία ἐστὶ τὸ τὸν ἔχοντα γαμετὶν· ἑτέραν προσφθαρεῖναι καὶ περὶ Χριστοῦ καὶ πορνικοῦ ἔρωτος:· Κύριε εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 90v Ἀγαπητοὶ· τὸ προσηνὲς καὶ λεῖον, οὐ πανταχοῦ χρήσιμον
msItem.explicit: f. 101r μεθ'οὗ τῶ Πατρὶ δόξα, ἅμα τῶ Ἁγίω Πνεύματι· εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: De perfecta caritate
msItem.rubric: f. 101r Τοῦ αὐτοῦ , λόγος περὶ ἀγάπης τελείας· καὶ τῆς κατὰ ἀξίας τῶν ἔργων ἀνταποδώσεως· καὶ περὶ τῆς δευτέρας τοῦ Χριστοῦ παρουσίας, Δέσποτα εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 101r Πᾶσα πράξις ἀγαθὴ, καρπὸς ἀγάθης ἐστίν
msItem.explicit: f. 129r μεθ'οὗ τῶ Πατρὶ ἅμα τῶ Ἁγίω Πνεύματι· δόξα τιμὴ καὶ προσκύνησις· νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: Ephraem Syrus (303-373)
msItem.title: Oratio in vanam vitam, et de paenitentia
msItem.note: Often spuriously attributed, as here, to John Chrysostom
msItem.rubric: f. 129r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· λόγος εἰς τὸν μάταιον βίον τοῦ κόσμου καὶ εἰς κατάνυξιν καὶ ὀφέλειαν τῶν ψυχῶν ἡμῶν: Εὐλόγησον δέσποτα
msItem.incipit: f. 129r Ὅσοι τὰ τοῦ βίου μάταια καὶ ἀπολλύμενα πράγματα κατελείπατε
msItem.explicit: f. 140r καὶ σου ἐστιν ἡ βασιλεία καὶ ἡ δόξα τοῦ Πατρὸς καὶ τοῦ Υἱοῦ καὶ τοῦ Ἁγίου Πνεύματος. νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: In Iohannem homiliae 1-88
msItem.note: Excerpt: ends at PG 59, col. 403; duplicates text on ff. 74v-76r
msItem.rubric: f. 140r <Τ>οῦ αὐτοῦ περὶ φιλοχρηματίας λόγος καὶ περὶ πλουσίων καὶ φιλαργύρων, καὶ διὰ τί εἴρηται εἰδωλολατρεία ἡ φιλαργυρία· καὶ περὶ ἐλεημοσύνης καὶ μετανοίας, Κύριε εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 140r <Ἀ>γαπητοὶ· ἀκολουθήσωμεν ἀγαθῶ δεσπότη θέλοντι τὴν σωτηρίαν ἡμῶν
msItem.explicit: f. 141v αἱ μὲν εἰσὶν ἀναγκαῖαι· αἱ δὲ, φυσικαὶ· αἱ δὲ οὐδ ἕτερον

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: Ad illuminandos catechesis 1
msItem.rubric: f. 142r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· κατήχησις πρὸς τοὺς μέλλοντας φωτίζεσθαι· καὶ περὶ γυναικῶν τῶν ἐν πλἐγμασιν καὶ χρυσῶ κατακοσμουσῶν ἑαυτὰς· καὶ περὶ ἄπτοις· ἢ ἐπ'ὠδαῖς κεχρημένω· ἅτινα ἅπαντα, ἀλλότρια χριστιανισμοῦ ἀποδέδεικται: Κύριε εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 142r Τῶν πρώην εἰρημένων πρὸς τὴν ἡμετέραν ἀγάπην
msItem.explicit: f. 167r μεθ'οὗ τῶ Πατρὶ δόξα· ἅμα τῶ Ἁγίω Πνεύματι, εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: In epistulam I ad Thessalonicenses homiliae 1-11
msItem.rubric: f. 167v Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν, Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· εἰς τὸ ῥήτον τοῦ ἀποστόλου, τοῦτο γὰρ ὑμῖν λέγομεν ἐν λόγω Κυρίου· ὅτι ἡμεῖς οἱ ζῶντες οἱ περιλοιπόμενοι εἰς τὴν παρουσίαν τοῦ Κυρίου, οὐ μὴ φθάσωμεν τοὺς κοιμηθέντας, Κύριε εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 167v Οἱ προφῆται μὲν τὸ ἀξιόπιστον τῶν λεγομένων δεῖξαι βουλόμενοι
msItem.explicit: f. 194r δόξα κράτος τιμὴ προσκύνησις· μεγαλοσύνη τε καὶ μεγαλοπρέπιεα, νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: In Genesim sermo 3
msItem.rubric: f. 194v Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν, Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· Λόγος εἰς τὴν ἀρχὴν τῆς ἁγίας τεσσαρακοστῆς καὶ εἰς τὴν ἐξορίαν του Ἀδάμ· καὶ περὶ πονηρῶν γυναικῶν:- εὐλόγησον δέσποτα
msItem.incipit: f. 194v Πρόκειται ἡμῖν ἀγαπητοὶ πνευματικὴ τράπεζα ἐκ τῶν θείων γραφῶν ἔργων
msItem.explicit: f. 236v ἐφάνη ναὸς καὶ θρόνος πανάγιος τοῦ Υἱοῦ τοῦ Θεοῦ· ἥτις τῆς

collation.p: This part consists of 32 quires. The reconstruction of a few quires in the collation presented here is conjectural, but on this basis this part contains one binion and one ternion, while the rest of the quires are quaternia. Quire 28 (ff. 213-220) is bound out of order and should follow Quire 29 (ff. 221-228).

list.item: Quire 44-1 ff. 17-19 One folio has been cancelled, without loss of text (this reconstruction is conjectural).
Quire 118-3 ff. 68-72 The first and last folios have been lost, with loss of text, while the fifth has been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 128-3 ff. 73-78 The first folio has been lost, with loss of text, while the last has become detached and misplaced (f. 87).
Quire 148+1 ff. 87-95 The detached last folio of Quire 12 has been attached to the beginning of this quire.
Quire 258+2 ff. 177-186 Two folios detached from Quire 27 have been inserted after the seventh folio of this quire.
Quire 276-4 ff. 195-196 The first and last folios of this quire have been lost, with loss of text, and the second and third folios have been detached and inserted into Quire 25 (ff. 184-185).

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 1r-236v A single column of 19 lines.
123 80

handNote.p: ff. 1r-236v were copied by Hand F in a blocky mixed minuscule script, slanting slightly to the right, in brown ink, with little variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: Texts begin with ornamented minor initials in red ink, and some sections with simpler minor initials in red ink.
Transitions between texts are marked by vignettes in red or brown and red ink.

additions.p: There are occasional pen-trials and brief marginal notes in Greek by various hands (e.g. ff. 1r, 28r, 141v).
An ownership note of Ioannes Borelius (perhaps Giovanni Alfonso Borelli) appears on f. 28r: Liber Ioannis Borelii.

history.origin: This part was probably copied in the 14th century, as suggested by the style of script and the use of eastern paper.

msItem.author: Epiphanios of Constantia (c. 310-403)
msItem.title: Homilia in divini corporis sepulturam
msItem.rubric: f. 240r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἐπιφανίου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κύπρου· λόγος εἰς τὴν θεόσωμον ταφὴν τοῦ Κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ· καὶ εἰς τὸν Ἰωσὴφ τὸν ἐξ Ἀριμαθείας· καὶ εἰς τὴν ἐν τῶ Ἅδη τοῦ Κυρίου κατάβασιν τὴν μετὰ τὸ σωτήριον πάθος παραδόξως γενομένην· Κυρίου εὐλόγησον
msItem.incipit: f. 240r Τί τοῦτο σήμερον· σιγῆ πολλὴ ἐν τῆ γῆ· τί τοῦτο· σιγῆ λοιπὸν καὶ ἡρεμία πολλὴ
msItem.explicit: f. 252r καὶ τῶ παναγίω καὶ ζωοποιῶ Πνεύματι· νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: Sophronios of Jerusalem (c. 560-c. 638)
msItem.title: Life of St Mary of Egypt
msItem.rubric: f. 252v Βίος καὶ πολιτεία τῆς ὁσίας Μαρίας τῆς Αἰγυπτίας· συγγραφῆς παρα Σοφρονίου πατριάρχου Ἱεροσολύμων, εὐλόγησον Πατέρ
msItem.incipit: f. 252v Μυστήριον βασιλέως, κρύπτειν καλὸν· τάδε ἔργα τοῦ Θεοῦ, ἀνακηρύττειν ἔνδοξον
msItem.explicit: f. 293r πάντοτε νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ· καὶ εἰς τοὺς ἀπεράντους· καὶ ἀτελευτήτους αἰῶνας, τῶν αἰώνων ἀμήν
msItem.note: f. 293v is blank apart from some later notes

msItem.author: Gregory of Nazianzus (c. 335-c. 394)
msItem.title: In sanctum Pascha et in tarditatem
msItem.rubric: f. 294r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Γρηγορίου τοῦ θεολόγου, ἐπισκόπου Ναζιανζοῦ· λόγος εἰς τὸ ἄγιον Πάσχα καὶ εἰς τὴν βραδυτῆτα, εὐλόγησον, Πατέρ
msItem.incipit: f. 294r Ἀναστάσεως ἡμέρα, καὶ ἡ ἀρχὴ δεξιὰ· καὶ λαμπρυνθῶμεν τῇ πανηγύρει
msItem.explicit: f. 297v νῦν τε καὶ εἰς τὴν ἐκεῖθεν ἀνάπαυσιν· ὦ ἡ δόξα καὶ τὸ κράτος· εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: Gregory of Nazianzus (c. 335-c. 394)
msItem.title: In theophania
msItem.rubric: f. 298r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν· Γρηγορίου τοῦ θεολόγου· λόγος· εἰς τὴν ἁγίαν τοῦ Χριστοῦ γέννησιν· εὐλόγησον Πατέρ
msItem.incipit: f. 298r Χριστὸς γεννᾶτε, δοξάσατε· Χριστὸς ἐξ οὐρανῶν, ἀπαντήσατε
msItem.explicit: f. 314v ἐν Χριστῶ Ἰησοῦ τῶ Κυρίω ἡμῶν· ὦ ἡ δόξα καὶ τὸ κράτος· εἰς τους αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων ἀμήν

msItem.author: Gregory of Nazianzus (c. 335-c. 394)
msItem.title: In sancta lumina
msItem.rubric: f. 315r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Γρηγορίου τοῦ θεολόγου· λόγος, εἰς τὰ ἅγια φῶτα ευλόγησον, Πατέρ
msItem.incipit: f. 315r Πάλιν Ἰησοῦς ὁ ἐμὸς, καὶ πάλιν μυστύριον· μυστήριον, οὐκ απατηλὸν οὐδὲ ἄκοσμον
msItem.explicit: f. 335v ἐν Χριστῶ Ἰησοῦ τῷ Κυρίω ἡμῶν· ᾧ ἡ δόξα καὶ τὸ κράτος· εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: Gregory of Antioch (d. c. 593)
msItem.title: Homilia I in sacra theophania
msItem.rubric: f. 336r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου· Κωνσταντινουπόλεως τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· λόγος ῥηθεὶς εἰς τὸ βάπτισμα καὶ εἰς τὴν σύναξιν τοῦ προδρόμου· εὐλόγησον, Πατέρ
msItem.incipit: f. 336r Ἄνδρες φιλόχριστοι καὶ φιλάδελφοι· καὶ φιλόξενοι· ξενοδοχήσατε τὴν ἐμὴν γλῶσσαν σήμερον
msItem.explicit: f. 347r μεθ'οὗ τῷ Πατρὶ δόξα· σὺν τῶ παναγίω καὶ ζωοποιῶ Πνεύματι, νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν

msItem.author: John Chrysostom (d. 407)
msItem.title: In annuntiationem beatae Mariae virginis
msItem.rubric: f. 347r Τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Ἰωάννου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Κωνσταντινουπόλεως, τοῦ Χρυσοστόμου· λόγος εἰς τὸν ευαγγελισμὼν τῆς ὑπεραγίας Θεοτόκου, εὐλόγησον Πατέρ
msItem.incipit: f. 347r Πάλιν χαρὰς εὐαγγέλια· πάλιν ἐλευθερίας μημύνατα· πάλιν ἀνάκλησις
msItem.explicit: f. 355r χάριτι καὶ φιλανθρωπία τοῦ Κυρίου ἡμῶν Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ· ὧ ἡ δόξα καὶ τὸ κράτος· εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν
msItem.finalRubric: f. 355r Νίκα τῷ συντελευτῆ τῶν καλῶν Θεῷ χάρις
msItem.note: f. 355v is blank apart from some later notes

collation.p: This part consists of 16 quires. The reconstruction of a few quires in the collation presented here is conjectural, but on this basis this part contains three ternia and one single bifolio, while the rest of the quires are quaternia. Quire 34 (ff. 249-256) is bound out of order and should follow Quire 35 (ff. 257-263 and the last folio belonging to this quire, now misplaced as f. 248).

list.item: Quire 338-2+3 ff. 240-248 The first and last original folios of this quire have been lost, but subsequently replaced with substitutes; the detached last folio of Quire 35 has been added to the end of this quire.
Quire 358-1 ff. 257-263 The last folio of this quire has been detached and added to Quire 32.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. 241r-246v, 248r-355r A single column of 21-23 lines. 139 90

handNote.p: ff. 241r-246v and 248r-355r were copied by Hand G in calligraphic mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in black ink, with significant variation in letter size and frequent flourishing of tails into the margin.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript or absent. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings, and nomina sacra strokes.
The flat-bottomed omega and loop epsilon are present, and there are inclusions of letters within omicron.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in Alexandrine majuscule style in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: Texts begin with ornamented minor initials in red ink, and some sections with simpler minor initials in red ink.
Transitions between texts are marked by vignettes in red or brown and red ink.

physDesc.additions: There are occasional pen-trials and brief marginal notes in Greek by various hands (e.g. ff. 251r, 293v-294r, 346v).

history.origin: This part was probably copied in the 14th century, as suggested by the style of script and the use of eastern paper.

supportDesc.collation: This part consists of two substitute folios replacing lost original folios in Quire 33.

layoutDesc.layout:
ff. 240r-240v, 247r-247v A single column of 22-23 lines. 142 90
Pricking does not survive. Ruled in hardpoint, type similar to Leroy 10D1. Text hangs from the lines.

handNote.p: ff. 240r-240v and 247r-247v were copied by Hand H in mixed minuscule script, slanting slightly to the right, in brown ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, abbreviations and nomina sacra strokes.
The sigma telikon is present.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma, question mark and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections begin with simple minor initials in red ink.

history.origin: This part was probably copied in the 14th century, as suggested by the style of script and the use of eastern paper

msItem.title: Euchologion
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning: begins ed. Goar, p. 290
msItem.incipit: f. [xi] recto ἀκου>σί<ων ἀμαρτημάτων ἄφεσιν αὐτοῖς δω>ρη<σάμενος, αὐτὸς οὖν δέσποτα πολυ εὐσπλαγχνε, χάρισαι αὐτοῖς
msItem.explicit: f. [xi] verso Ὅσοι εἰς Χριστὸν ἐβαπτίσθητε Χριστὸν ἐνεδύσασθε Ἀλληλούϊα· Καὶ γίνεται ἀπόλυστι

msItem.title: Euchologion
msItem.note: Excerpt: baptismal prayer for a child close to death
Defective at the end: ends ed. Goar, p. 303
msItem.rubric: f. [xi] verso Ἑτέρα ἀκολουθία τοῦ ἁγίου βαπτίσματος· ἔχει τὸ προοίμιον πάνυ σύντομον εἰς τ[..]υτα π[..6..] βαπτιζώμενον κατά τινα [....]
msItem.incipit: f. [xi] verso Κύριε ὁ Θεὸς ὁ παντοκράτωρ· ὁ ποιήσας τὸν οὐρανὸν καὶ τὴν γῆν
msItem.explicit: f. [xi] verso σὺ συνέτριψας τὰς καὶφαλὰς τῶν δρακώντωω ἐ

supportDesc.collation: This part consists of a single folio reused as an endleaf.

layoutDesc.layout: f. [xi] recto-[xi] verso A single column of 20 lines. 142 100

handNote.p: f. [xi] recto-[xi] verso was copied by Hand I in mixed minuscule script, slanting slightly to the left, in black ink, with moderate variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot, and accentuation of all nomina sacra.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower comma and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: The text beginning on f. [xi] verso is preceded by a plaited headpiece outlined in black ink with red infill.
Sections begin with simple minor initials in brown ink.

history.origin: This fragment was reused here as an endleaf. This manuscript from which it comes was probably copied in the 14th century, as suggested by the style of script and the use of eastern paper.

msItem.title: Hymns
msItem.note: Defective at the beginning and end, with lacunas
msItem.incipit: f. [xiii] verso μιωθήσης· διὸ εἷς, καὶ ὁ αὐτὸς αμφωτερ
msItem.explicit: f. [xii] recto αμφοιν, καὶ δι'ενος αμφό

collation.p: This part consists of part of a single bifolio reused as endleaves, with much of its outer and lower parts missing.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. [xii] recto-[xiii] verso A single column of at least 27 lines. 147 105

handNote.p: f. [xii] recto-[xiii] verso were copied by Hand J in mixed minuscule script, slanting slightly to the right, in black ink, with minimal variation in letter size and some flourishing of tails into the margin.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. Use of the double dot is functional only, and nomina sacra are unaccentuated.
Punctuation used includes the upper point, middle comma and full stop.

decoDesc.decoNote: Items begin with simple minor initials in black ink.

history.origin: This fragment was resued here as an endleaf. The fragment from which it comes was probably copied in the 12th century, as suggested by the style of script.
